results.adx_keywords: Stroke;Brain;Language and Languages;Babies and Infants;Tests (Medical);Research;your-feed-science;Massachusetts Institute of Technology
results.title: The Curious Hole in My Head
results.abstract: Born without my left temporal lobe, a brain region thought to be critical for language, I’ve been a research subject for much of my life.

media.caption: Helen Santoro, left, examining a scan of her brain with her mother at an M.I.T. lab in Cambridge, Mass., in July.
media.copyright: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Books and Literature;Writing and Writers;Content Type: Personal Profile;Man Booker Prize;Strout, Elizabeth
results.title: At 66, Elizabeth Strout Has Reached Maximum Productivity
results.abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author has written five books in six years and been nominated for a Booker Prize for “Oh William!” What’s gotten into her?

media.caption: “It’s like I’ve been training for a marathon my entire life,” said Strout, “and now there’s an acceleration happening.”
media.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Rivers;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Land Use Policies;Wilderness Areas;Trespassing;High Net Worth Individuals;Conservation of Resources;Fishing, Sport;Rafts;Trout;Water;internal-sub-only;Colorado;Arkansas River
results.title: Does This Fisherman Have the Right to Be in a Billionaire’s Backyard?
results.abstract: A fight along Colorado’s waterways pits an alliance of white-water rafters and amateur anglers against some of the nation’s wealthiest landowners, bruising the image of a sportsman’s paradise.

media.caption: Roger Hill, a fly fisherman, in the Arkansas River east of Cotopaxi, Colo. He has sued to have the state clarify its laws around one of his favorite fly-fishing grounds.
media.copyright: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times

results.title: After a Long, Starring Run, Will Racism at Last Get the Hook?
results.abstract: We can no longer ignore the theater’s systemic inequities. But leaving them behind may remake the industry in unexpected ways.
org_facet: We See You, White American Theater (Theater Coalition)

results.title: Ken Burns Explores America’s Inaction During the Holocaust
results.abstract: “The U.S. and the Holocaust,” coming to PBS Sept. 18, examines the reasons behind the country’s inadequate response to Germany’s persecution of Jews.

media.caption: “The U.S. and the Holocaust” is Ken Burns’s latest deep dive into America’s past.

results.abstract: All kinds of kids, from all kinds of families — rich, poor and middle class — need more help with reading than they’re getting in school.

results.adx_keywords: Restaurants;Cooking and Cookbooks;Vegetarianism;Moosewood (Ithaca, NY, Restaurant);Ithaca (NY)
results.title: Moosewood, the Beloved Vegetarian Restaurant, Prepares for Its Second Act
results.abstract: The Ithaca, N.Y., destination was revolutionary because of its menu and its collective ownership model. Recently, the new owners hosted a dinner to celebrate its past and future.

media.caption: The dinner, which featured sweet pea hummus; baby beet salad; Orecchiette with pea shoots, carrots and French radishes; and chickpea stew with panisses, was served family style.

results.title: In South Korea, a Hit Show Brings Autism Into the Spotlight
results.abstract: “Extraordinary Attorney Woo” has raised awareness of autism in South Korea, where developmental disabilities are still a taboo subject for many people.

media.caption: Teaching a child at Autism Partnership Korea, a center for young children with autism in Seoul.
media.copyright: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

results.title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
results.abstract: Everyone and their mother seems to be playing. What’s the draw — and is it really a workout?

results.adx_keywords: Campaign Finance;Midterm Elections (2022);Elections, Senate;United States Politics and Government;Scott, Richard L;National Republican Senatorial Committee;Republican Party
results.title: How a Record Cash Haul Vanished for Senate Republicans
results.abstract: The campaign arm of Senate Republicans had collected $181.5 million by the end of July — but spent 95 percent of it. A big investment in digital, and hyperaggressive tactics, have not paid off.

media.caption: Senator Rick Scott of Florida oversaw an enormous wave of spending on digital ads at the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
media.copyright: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

results.title: A Baby Hadn’t Gained Any Weight in Months. Why Was It Failing to Thrive?
results.abstract: The 5-month-old boy’s blood sodium levels were dangerously high. The parents were desperate for answers.

results.adx_keywords: Biographical Information;Jews and Judaism;Rabbis;Holocaust and the Nazi Era;World War II (1939-45);Women and Girls;Jonas, Regina (1902-44);Germany
results.title: Overlooked No More: Regina Jonas, Upon Whose Shoulders ‘All Female Rabbis Stand’
results.abstract: Jonas was officially ordained as a rabbi in Germany in 1935, just as conditions were worsening for Jews. She was killed at Auschwitz when she was 42.

media.caption: Regina Jonas in 1936, a year after she was officially ordained as the world’s first woman rabbi.
media.copyright: Stiftung Neue Synagoge Berlin — Centrum Judaicum

results.title: Town After Town, Residents Are Fighting Affordable Housing in Connecticut
results.abstract: Local residents and elected officials are seeking to block large housing projects, warning that increased density could change the character of their towns.

results.title: In a Japanese Nursing Home, Some Workers Are Babies
results.abstract: They get paid in formula and diapers, and their work hours are flexible, in a program that connects people across generations and brightens lives.

media.caption: A “baby worker” at the Ichoan Nursing Home in Kitakyushu, Japan.

results.title: Dressing for Hot: How a Warming Planet Is Changing What We Wear
